snippet: A ruling by the Court of Appeals could affect other tenants in buildings that are covered by the 1982 Loft Law and that haven’t been brought up to residential standards.
abstract: New York State Court of Appeals rules that a Brooklyn loft tenant Margaret Maugenest, who has not paid rent since 2003, cannot be evicted because the landlord has not brought the building up to residential standards; ruling could affect tenants in other buildings covered by the 1982 Loft Law, which has allowed hundreds of former manufacturing or commercial buildings to be rented to tenants as long as landlords make necessary changes to bring them up to residential building codes.
lead_paragraph: A ruling by the Court of Appeals could affect other tenants in buildings that are covered by the 1982 Loft Law and that haven’t been brought up to residential standards.
